lead_paragraph: One of the most memorable classes I took in business school was an elective called “Management as Seen by the Arts.” It was taught by Professor Culbertson, a character straight out central casting if ever there was one: Harvard-educated, bespectacled, gray hair and beard, slight paunch concealed by a tweed jacket with leather elbow patches. We read “Bonfire of the Vanities” and “Death of a Salesman,” and we discussed how drastically the economic landscape had changed since the filming of “Norma Rae.”

Without going into a lot of specifics, no, you do not want to draw a bath, light candles and read O magazine in the tub. But, yes, the iPad works great with other appliances in that room.

abstract: One in a series about how the iPad might land in the hands of consumers.

lead_paragraph: You are shopping for a house in an unfamiliar town with your partner and a 3G-equipped iPad. You fire up Zillow, a real estate app, and it shows you everything that is for sale. As you drive, a rolling list appears and you see a domicile in your price range. You pull up in front of a house that looks perfectly quaint and lovely. You open up the digital listing and discover through photos that the people who own it are either “Leave It to Beaver” nostalgics or have not redecorated since it was a well-rated show. You finger drop it from your list of favorites and keep moving, on to the next highlighted property on your illustrated wish list.

lead_paragraph: You are finished working and on an airplane watching the in-flight movie, “Hannah Montana: The Movie.” For the second time. The person next to you pulls out an iPad and opens up “Broken Embraces,” a movie you are dying to see. Your seatmate has headphones on, but even from the side, the images of Penelope Cruz are achingly, gorgeously beautiful. You stay with the movie by glancing sidelong at the subtitles and vow that sometime after you land, you are going to buy one of these suckers. You can’t sit next to it and not want it.

lead_paragraph: You are in a Wi-Fi hot spot and want to catch up on some news. You check your usual traps, scanning headlines, and you begin to notice holes everywhere. You’ve read about how the iPad doesn’t play Flash, the main video application on the Web, but you’ve never realized how much of your news now comes in video form. You realize that even though the future is here, for the time being, much of it will not be televised.

Sweat begins dripping on beautiful screen as you realize that the keypad, sufficient for Tweeting, emailing and I’Ming, is not the app you want when you catch a red ball from work.

lead_paragraph: Your mother-in-law hates computers. Hates. Them. “Too old, too stupid,” she says. She comes for a Christmas visit and you show her pictures from your daughter’s kindergarten graduation. She watches with increasing interest as you scatter and scan the photos with a flick of the finger. She takes a turn and it goes well. Then you show her the YouTube video of the fall pageant. The satellite map of your childhood home. She takes a turn and this time she does not give it back. You leave her alone for an hour and come back to find her scanning recipes on Epicurious. “This isn’t really a computer,” she says. “It can’t be. I actually might like having one of these around.” Is that so? Merry Christmas, beloved, Luddite mother-in-law. We bought it for you.

headline.main: The iPad Consumer Case #9: This Is Your Grandma’s Oldsmobile

abstract: John Malkovich, the actor, is seeking to recover $2.3 million from an account he had with the securities firm of Bernard L. Madoff.

lead_paragraph: John Malkovich, the actor, is seeking to recover $2.3 million from an account he had with the securities firm of Bernard L. Madoff. Irving H. Picard, the trustee liquidating Mr. Madoff’s firm, approved a claim in August for $670,000 for the actor’s pension plan and trust, more than $1.5 million short of the value of the securities listed on the November 2008 final statement of Mr. Malkovich’s account, lawyers for the actor said in a filing Thursday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. Mr. Picard told Mr. Malkovich he was not entitled to the full amount because no securities were purchased for his account and the approved claim reflects what he deposited with Mr. Madoff’s firm, according to the filing. The actor’s lawyers said Mr. Malkovich was owed the full amount on his final statement.

headline.main: John Malkovich Seeks Bigger Madoff Return
headline.print_headline: John Malkovich Seeks Bigger Madoff Return

abstract: When Charles O. Prince III and Robert E. Rubin testify on Thursday about Citigroup, there is a chance to address a sense that on Wall Street, even big mistakes have no consequences.

lead_paragraph: On Thursday, two of the biggest — and among the most tarnished — names on Wall Street will testify in front of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission in Washington: Charles O. Prince III, the former chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, and Robert E. Rubin, a former top adviser and director of the bank. On the watch of these men, Citigroup lost more money than almost any company in history, requiring an extraordinary government bailout.

abstract: Greece has a huge debt burden, but perhaps a limited default with modest write-downs would ease its predicament.

lead_paragraph: Forget about Greece for a moment. Just think about country X, which has lived well beyond its means for years thanks to loans from inattentive or foolishly optimistic lenders. When the financial crisis comes, the people of the country will have to cut back on spending. And the country’s lenders will generally suffer from the famous rule of banking: “Can’t pay, won’t pay.”

headline.main: A Daring Proposal to Rescue Greece

lead_paragraph: For the past 25 years, Bob Garfield has written the AdReview column for Advertising Age, but on Monday he filed for the last time. AdReview was a witty and sometimes withering deconstruction of all manner of advertising campaigns that had many fans. But Mr. Garfield said he was hanging it up, in part, because, “if my grand apocalyptic theories about advertising and media are correct, that’s a lot of my eggs in a couple of quickly disintegrating baskets.”

Yesterday I was here meeting my client, wearing a suit and tie and looking slick. Today I got up at 4 a.m. to drive the truck and deliver the job. Yesterday I went in the front door; today I take the freight elevator. Did I get demoted overnight? No, I’m the boss. I need this delivery to go smoothly, and the recession has thinned my work force, so here I am — parking the truck.

abstract: Much to his own amazement, a small-business owner found he was pretty good at design and sales. Which is why he didn’t fail immediately.

lead_paragraph: My company makes custom furniture. I started the company shortly after graduating from the University of Pennsylvania in 1985. I was working that summer as a carpenter’s helper, thinking that some construction experience would serve me well when designing buildings.

abstract: When the annual sales-and-marketing plan is presented at this company, the associates are asked to vote on their confidence level. Last June, the results weren’t so good.
snippet: When the annual sales-and-marketing plan is presented at this company, the associates are asked to vote on their confidence level. Last June, the results weren’t so good.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of June 22, 2009, all 78 associates of SRC Power Systems, which makes custom-engineered power units and is based in Springfield, Mo., filed onto the shop floor to hear an hour-long presentation about the company’s latest sales-and-marketing plan. People grabbed folding chairs where available while others sat on wire containers or floor baskets near their tools and workstations. There was a dark mood in the air. One guy leaned up against an engine crate, his arms folded across his chest and his jaw set. It was as if he already didn’t like what he was about to hear.

headline.main: How We Try to Get Buy-In, Part 1

abstract: Tensions between Twitter and its developers and an interview with Dean Kamen, the inventor of the Segway, top this week’s Tech Talk podcast.
snippet: Tensions between Twitter and its developers and an interview with Dean Kamen, the inventor of the Segway, top this week’s Tech Talk podcast.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein finds out why Twitter app developers are worried. She speaks with Claire Cain Miller, The Times technology reporter who covers Twitter, about the company’s moves toward building its own tools for the microblogging service, and the concerns among developers who fear that Twitter might turn into a competitor. Independent developers have created some 70,000 apps that let users do things like track messages on cellphones, monitor multiple Twitter accounts, shorten link addresses and post photos on the service.Dean Kamen, inventor of the Segway, is also a strong advocate of promoting science and technology education. J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Mr. Kamen about his own early inspirations and about the nonprofit group he founded to encourage interest in these fields among the young. The organization, called First  (For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology), holds its 19th annual championship, with competitions in robotics, gaming and Lego construction, April 15-17 at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta.You might expect your brand new computer to have a clean hard drive, only to find programs installed on it that you didn’t ask for, or trial versions of software that pester you to buy the full version or sign up for a service. There is a name for that, as Pedro Rafael Rosado explains in his regularly featured audio essay on tech terms.Also on the show, Ms. Biersdorfer rounds up tech news of the week, including updates for the Google Docs service, a new fleet of MacBook Pro laptops from Apple; Neflix streaming movies via Wii game consoles; and prepackaged movies on portable Seagate drives. And if you can’t wait for baseball season to start, her tech tip of the week can help you get set: MySportsCal lets you download your favorite team’s schedule right into your Outlook, iCal or Google calendar.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: Dean Kamen

abstract: Just who are those women who may make people break up?
snippet: Just who are those women who may make people break up?
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I love clues like “Company with the stock symbol DPZ.” I’m sure there are a few day traders out there who knew that answer immediately but for most of us, it’s the kind of clue that seems impossible at first. Hmmm. It probably starts with D. But what is that PZ all about? I bet it only took you a few seconds. Same with the 2006 Rihanna song “___ Been the One.” I don’t know who Rihanna is but by applying a little standard crossword logic, I was able to fill the blank from just the first letter. How about that novel with the chapter “Farming in Polynesia?” You’ve never read that book but if you’ve been doing crosswords for a while, you filled in that four-letter answer immediately. Does this mean crosswords are making us smarter? Or just filling our heads with useless trivia? Either way, it’s fun.

headline.main: Women Who May Make People Break Up

abstract: A Saturday puzzle by Tim Croce provides a bit of parental diversion.
snippet: A Saturday puzzle by Tim Croce provides a bit of parental diversion.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — You’re right, that’s a purposely salacious blog post title. Let me atone by tackling the bible clues first because they’re both terrific. “Biblical spot” ought to be EDEN but that’s not enough letters. There’s a lot of complex geography in those testaments but fortunately we don’t need to know any of it here as long as we’re reading the right translation. Spot is a verb. Thou SEEST? What about “Fall cuisine?” Yes, that’s biblical too but APPLE is wrong. I laughed when the answer finally came to me like MANNA from heaven.

headline.main: Strip in a Bar

abstract: NXP Semiconductors, the Dutch chipmaker, filed to raise $1.15 billion in what would be the biggest initial public offering in the United States this year.
snippet: NXP Semiconductors, the Dutch chipmaker, filed to raise $1.15 billion in what would be the biggest initial public offering in the United States this year.
lead_paragraph: NXP Semiconductors, the Dutch chipmaker owned by KKR & Company and Bain Capital, filed to raise $1.15 billion in what would be the biggest initial public offering in the United States this year. NXP did not disclose the number of shares it intends to sell or at what price range in its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday. The chipmaker, which is based in Eindhoven, The Netherlands, and has reported losses for three straight years, plans to use the proceeds to repay debt. NXP, with 27,000 employees, makes computer chips for a broad range of electronic device makers such as Nokia Oyj and Apple, according to the filing.

headline.main: Chipmaker in the Netherlands Plans to Sell Shares
headline.print_headline: Chipmaker In the Netherlands Plans To Sell Shares

abstract: A report by the S.E.C.’s inspector general, H. David Kotz, disclosed that the commission did not conduct a meaningful investigation of the indicted money manager R. Allen Stanford until 2005.
snippet: A report by the S.E.C.’s inspector general, H. David Kotz, disclosed that the commission did not conduct a meaningful investigation of the indicted money manager R. Allen Stanford until 2005.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission did not conduct a meaningful investigation of the indicted money manager R. Allen Stanford until 2005 even though examiners suspected him of operating a Ponzi scheme eight years earlier, a report by the S.E.C.’s inspector general, H. David Kotz, disclosed Friday. The S.E.C. sued Mr. Stanford in February 2009, claiming his Antigua-based firm, the Stanford International Bank, defrauded investors by selling billions of dollars in bogus certificates of deposit. He is jailed awaiting a January trial on related criminal charges that he oversaw a $7 billion Ponzi scheme.

headline.main: Internal Report Faults S.E.C. In Stanford Case
headline.print_headline: Internal Report Faults S.E.C. In Stanford Case

This recovery may anger the average investor who equates hedge funds with the bad deeds of Wall Street. And the funds’ quick return may surprise sophisticated investors who are still smarting from the money they lost in their rush to move their portfolios to cash.

Trying to master all areas, or at least sort them all out, can be frustrating, exhausting and scary. Entrepreneurship differs from many other “professions” in that by definition you are on your own: no colleagues back at the office, no mentor or boss to show you the way. In addition, it is not just your paycheck that is at risk; it can be everything you have, not to mention money put up by friends and family.

headline.main: Should You Join a Business Group?

abstract: After the financial collapse, an owner confronted a slowdown in orders, a pile of debt and a partner wanted to shut down the business.
snippet: After the financial collapse, an owner confronted a slowdown in orders, a pile of debt and a partner wanted to shut down the business.
lead_paragraph: The day after laying off half of my workers, I sat with the others in my office. They knew we were in trouble, but The Partner’s policy of silence had kept me from revealing just how bad it was. They were angry about being kept in the dark, and many were ready to quit. So I made a promise that from that day forward I would answer any question, any time, as completely and honestly as possible. I laid out for them what the near-term future would look like: we had work, but not much. More might be coming, but maybe not.

headline.main: Staying Alive: Crawling From the Wreckage

abstract: We have a Monday puzzle by Lynn Lempel and an announcement about a new Wordplay feature.
snippet: We have a Monday puzzle by Lynn Lempel and an announcement about a new Wordplay feature.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Are you a crossword fan or, more generally, a puzzle aficionado? The former probably knows or at least might be pleased to learn that the word “aficionado” implies not just a devotee, but an enthusiastic amateur. The latter might then view that as the start of a logic puzzle. Will Shortz can’t be an aficionado because he’s a professional, therefore the man in the blue house must smoke Lucky Strikes, or however that old syllogism goes. We’re going to do something a little risky, perhaps, by expanding the scope of Wordplay just a little. More on that further down.

headline.main: Doing Something Risky

Despite a record-setting $6.3 billion fourth quarter, online advertising revenue declined 3.4 percent for the year from 2008, the first year-over-year falloff since 2002. lead_paragraph: Greetings folks, and welcome to the new Numberplay section of the Wordplay blog, the reincarnation of the TierneyLab Monday Puzzle. abstract: Wall Street, of course. But so are the governments in Canada and Australia.
snippet: Wall Street, of course. But so are the governments in Canada and Australia.
lead_paragraph: You won’t be surprised to learn that Wall Street doesn’t like the idea of a bank tax. Wall Street lobbyists argue that a tax on banks — meant to discourage risky investments and cover the costs of financial crises — will keep banks from being able to lend to worthy borrowers. That’s not theoretically impossible, but it doesn’t seem very likely. The taxes under discussion would have a low rate. It’s also worth remembering that Wall Street’s lobbyists often claim that they are just looking out for the interests of borrowers.

headline.main: Who’s Afraid of a Bank Tax?

abstract: Well, yes, I do get bored easily. But I’m not the only one.
snippet: Well, yes, I do get bored easily. But I’m not the only one.
lead_paragraph: My first experience with a business group came about 20 years ago, when I tried to assemble my own. In theory, it seems like this should be an easy thing to do. It’s not. It is very hard to find enough people to get a group going — even if you’re not charging anything. And even if you do get it going, it can be difficult to keep it going. It feels like a full-time job because it is a full-time job – one that I wasn’t very good at and didn’t have time to do. My do-it-yourself group lasted less than a year and did not have the benefit of the resources that professional groups have, including the ability to recruit new members.

headline.main: Why I Keep Joining Business Groups

abstract: While I thought that apps that prevent you from calling, texting or e-mailing when you’re driving were worth a look, skeptics arguing that people won’t voluntarily give up their phones in the car do have a point.
snippet: While I thought that apps that prevent you from calling, texting or e-mailing when you’re driving were worth a look, skeptics arguing that people won’t voluntarily give up their phones in the car do have a point.
lead_paragraph: In my Times column this morning, I reviewed cellphone apps that prevent you from calling, texting or e-mailing when you're driving. I noted that they're far from perfect solutions. For one thing, they work only on BlackBerrys and Android phones at this point-a tiny percentage of all phones. And they can't distinguish between the motion of you, the driver, and the motion of you, a passenger in someone else's car or even on a train or a bus.

headline.main: Text-Blocking Apps Only Work if You Use Them

Rasch who is the former head of the United States Department of Justice computer crime unit, and helped develop the department’s guidelines for computer crimes related to investigations, forensics and evidence gathering.
